bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 167, Number 152 (Tuesday, August 31, 2021)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. CROW:H.R. 5133.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following: Article 1, Section 8 of the U.S.Constitution[Page H4501]

item.title: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2022

latestAction.text: Returned to the Calendar. Calendar No. 144.

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Armed Services.

summary.text:
Transparency in Reporting for an Accurate Count of Combat Equipment (TRACCE) Act

This bill requires the Department of Defense (DOD) to report the theft or loss of any ammunition, destructive device, or explosive material from its stocks to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives within the Department of Justice. Currently, DOD only reports on such thefts or losses to the Department of the Treasury.

The bill also requires DOD to annually report on all instances of missing, lost, or stolen weapons, large amounts of ammunition, destructive devices, or explosive material from its stocks.

bill.title: Transparency in Reporting for an Accurate Count of Combat Equipment (TRACCE) Act

item.title: Transparency in Reporting for an Accurate Count of Combat Equipment (TRACCE) Act
Transparency in Reporting for an Accurate Count of Combat Equipment (TRACCE) Act
To require an annual report on missing, lost, and stolen weapons, large amounts of ammunition, destructive devices, and explosive material, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Armed Services.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
